I think when you add a type parameter (<T extends Animal>) to the overridden method, it changes the method's signature enough to avoid the clash with the original method in the superclass, even if the return type is Dog.

I hope that helpful for you.

answers.body_markdown:
A whole chain of events are going wrong here.

Your key problem is that `abstract <T extends Animal> T createFromList(List<Object> cells);` is useless bordering on the 'necessarily buggy' terrain. Just because javac will compile it, doesn't mean it's sensible. It's at the `public int add(int a, int b) { return a - b; }` level - compiles, but, meaningless. Your question is therefore more or less irrelevant. Yes, there are answers to your questions. They are esoteric and weird. They are not the kind of knowledge that is useful at all when writing java code. Because the _cause_ of your questions is some nonsense code. The right fix is to get rid of the nonsense and then your questions have become moot.

### But first, context

The answer to your question isn't going to make sense unless you understand what generics _mean_. SO answers are ordinarily meant to assume all knowledge not explicitly stated in the question, but if you knew what it meant, you'd know the `AbstractClass` definition is nonsense which would make this a weird question. Hence, I'm assuming you don't understand the semantics that underlie generics.

When you write:

```
public <T extends Animal> T foo() {}
```

You're saying that, for each and every invocation of the `foo` method, the __caller__ picks some type T. And you __have no idea__ what T is. It could be anything. Your code needs to be written such that it is sensible and violates no typing rules __for every possible choice the caller could ever make__.

In other words, putting it in very slightly more familiar terms, if you have a method: `public void foo(List<? extends Animal> list)`, that is often interpreted to mean: "Foo takes as argument a list of animals. Animal, Dog, Cat, they all extend Animal, all are fine". __But that is wrong__. The question mark is the hint: It actually means: "Foo takes as argument a list of.. I don't actually know. It's question mark. However, I do know one thing: Whatever it actually is, it's a list of some UNKNOWN subtype of Animal. It could be a list of cats. It could be a list of dogs. It could be a list of animals. I do not know. The code must be sensible and make no type violations __regardless__ of what that list actually ends up being.

And that's why you __cannot__ `.add()` to such a list. Try it!

```
List<? extends Animal> foo = new ArrayList<>();
foo.add(new Dog()); // error
foo.add(new Cat()); // error
foo.add(new Animal()); // even if we make animal non-abstract, error
```

There is in fact --not a single thing-- you could possibly put in the parentheses after `add` that the compiler will compile. Except for the useless academic case of `foo.add(null);` (literally, `n`, `u`, `l`, `l`, not 'some variable whose value happens to be `null`', no, the null literal typed directly into your source code), and that's only because the null literal is every type all at the same time.

However, this is fine for such a list:

```
Animal a = list.get(0);
```

That's because, if all I know is that this is a list that contains who knows, all I know is, it's restricted to only contain certain things, and that restriction is also unknown, but I do know it's Animal or some subtype of it. Then, therefore, the first element in it, is necessarily assignable to `Animal`.

As a mirror image, `List<? super Dog>` lets you add dogs, but `.get()` is useless (the expression `listOfSuperDog.get(0)` is of type `Object`, but, just like with `null`, that's academic: In java that list cannot contain non-objects, so `Object o = list.get(0);` is safe for all lists regardless of generics restrictions.

After all, if you want to express the idea of a _list of animals_, we already have that in java. That's simply `List<Animal>`. Not `List<? extends Animal>`. All dogs are animals, so, you can _of course_ add a dog to a list of animals. Try it:

```
List<Animal> animals = new ArrayList<>();
animals.add(new Dog()); // fine
animals.add(new Cat()); // fine
```

`List<Animal>` is powerful in that you can add stuff to it, _and_ meaningfully get things from it, but it is incredibly restricted in that only literally `List<Animal>` will do. `List<Cat>` won't (you can't pass a variable of type `List<Cat>`  to a method whose first arg is `List<Animal>`. After all, you can add a dog to a `List<Animal>`, and now there's a dog amongst your cats, that's no good). In contrast, `List<? extends Animal>` is far less powerful: You can only get from it, you can't add anything. But, on the plus side, you __can__ pass a `List<Cat> to it. Given that you can't add anything to it, it's fine. There is no risk that this results in a dog amongst your cats.

## So why doesn't my code make sense?

Generics are a figment of the compiler's imagination. If it doesn't result in compile-time stuff (the compiler inserting some casts for you or giving you warnings or errors), __they cannot possibly do anything__. The runtime doesn't know what they are, doesn't verify them, care about them, or in any way care about it whatsoever. Hence, if a generics variable shows up only once, __it is useless__ - it serves to link things and how can it link things if it is only used once ever? You're either writing broken code or using generics for some weird hackery. Both are probably bad.

Here's a trivial example of how generics link things:

```
public <T> T nullOr(T left, T right) {
  return left == null ? right : left;
```

The generics link things: It says: Hey, caller? You can pick whatever type you want when you call me. I'm just telling you: The type of the first arg, the second arg, and the return type are __linked__. They are the same for any given call to `nullOr`. And the compiler ensures that your code makes sense and adheres to this linkage you've set up.

Your:

```
abstract <T extends Animal> T createFromList(List<Object> cells);
```

Is therefore just utterly broken:

1. It declares a typevar and uses it once. Insta red flag.
2. Every caller gets to pick a value for T. One caller thinks its Cat. Another thinks its Dog. Any `createFromList` implementation has no idea what it is (given that they are a figment of the compiler's imagination, there is no way to ask at runtime what type it is), and therefore __it is not possible to write a non-broken implementation of this method, period__<sup>1</sup>.

## Answer my questions then!

In your first case:

```
@Override Dog createFromList(Object cells) {}
```

The compiler can 'make it work' by moving to 'raw' mode. raw mode for `javac` is an all or nothing deal. If some signature, override, or expression involves raw code, then __all of it__ turns raw. There is no picking and choosing.

Ordinarily you trivially get raw mode when you fail to add `<>` where they are ordinarily required. However, this is an exotic case where you also get raw mode.

## Huh? Why is this raw?

Let's first go with: What if it __is not__ raw. The compiler has to ensure your code works _for all possible choices_. And it doesn't. After all, if the caller chooses `Cat`, well, a Dog is no Cat, so your method simply fails at a fundamental level (i.e. it wouldn't compile in the first place). `Dog foo()` cannot possibly be an override of `Cat foo()`, and yet, `Cat` is a possible choice you have to cater to. You don't, so this __cannot__ be normal mode.

In raw mode, however, _it does work_. In raw mode, __all generics__ revert to their lower bound. Which, here, is Animal. And you can 'tighten the return type'. If you have an abstract method that requires that all impls return an `Animal`, then having an impl that only returns Cat is fine. Cats are animals, after all. The key difference is, going back to the 'context' lesson up top, that `<? extends Animal>` doesn't mean 'Animal or any subtype of it'. It means: "I do not know. Could be Cat. Could be Dog". Key part of that sentence is: __Could be Cat__. Returning 'Dog' when your supermethod asks that you return 'Animal' is fine. Returning 'Dog' when your supermethod asks that you return 'Cat' __is not__.

## Now explain my compiler error

Looking at `AbstractClass`:

```
// what you wrote:
<T extends Animal> T createCells(List<Object> object);

// the raw mode version of that signature:
Animal createCells(List object);
```

I mentioned raw mode is an all or nothing deal. Thus, __all of it__ becomes raw. Notably including the `List` parameter!

In order to have `Dog` work as the return type, javac has to switch to raw type. Which it can, but that means `List` is also raw, and `List<Object>` isn't, per the JLS, compatible with raw list when showing up in your signature like this.

This also explains why `@Override Dog createFromList(List /* raw */ cells) {}` __does__ work.

## Do not ignore compiler warnings

Forget about your trials and tribulations with the compiler errors for a moment. Let's just look at `AbstractClass`. I can write this:

```
AbstractClass ac = whoKnowsHowIGetOne();
Cat cat = ac.createFromCells("hello");
```

and javac compiles it fine. After all, it's _the caller_ that gets to pick generics bounds and this code totally makes sense if we pick 'Cat'. So `javac` picks that. However, your actual impl returns Dog. Java makes `ac.createFromCells("hello")` work here by silently injecting an invisible cast. Which means when I call your Dog-returning version, I get a ClassCastException. On a line that... has zero casts on it. Oof, that's confusing.

This gets us back to: There is no point to the `createFromCells` method. Either one. It's not possible.

## What you possibly meant

Perhaps you meant to write this:

```
class AbstractClass<T extends Animal> {
  abstract T createFromCells(Object obj);
  abstract T createFromCells(List<Object> list);
}
```

Now the generics aren't useless. The declared T is now actually used in _3_ places: The constructor of `AbstractClass` (constructors silently inherit all type-level declared type vars), the return type of one method, and the return type of a second method. You can now write, without any generics warnings at all:

```
class DogMaker extends AbstractClass<Dog> {
  @Override public Dog createFromCells(Object obj) { .. }
  @Override public Dog createFromCells(List<Object> obj) { .. }
}
```

No warnings. No compiler errors. All works great.

-------

[1] Non-hacky situations where 'declare type var, use it only once' is valid is when the return type is never going to matter at runtime. For example, a method that _always_ throws (it cannot ever 'return normally' with a `return;` statement). Or one that always returns literally `null`. Having such a method is borderline hacky in the first place (why does it declare that it returns a value of type `Foo` when the method cannot actually ever normally return?). Hence, the simple rule of thumb remains: "Typevars declared and used exactly once are a red flag".

items.title: Overriding methods with generic return types
items.body:
I do not understand this completely. Let's say I have this simple hierarchy:

class Animal { }
class Dog extends Animal {}
class Cat extends Animal {}
...

And this abstract class:

abstract class AbstractClass {
  abstract <T extends Animal> T createFromList(List<Object> cells);
  abstract <T extends Animal> T createFromObj(Object cells);
}

And a subclass derived from it:

class SubClass extends AbstractClass {}

Within the derived class SubClass I'm allowed to override createFromObj like shown below. We will result in a warning but the class will still compile:

  @Override
  Dog createFromObj(Object cells) {...}

I understand that. The same is not true if I override the other method:

  @Override
  Dog createFromList(List<Object> cells) {...}

This will lead to a compilation error:

'createFromList(List<Object>)' in 'SubClass' clashes with 'createFromList(List<Object>)' in 'AbstractClass'; both methods have same erasure, yet neither overrides the other

Override details - here.

Okay, but what puzzles me is that this will compile:

  @Override
  <T extends Animal> T createFromList(List<Object> cells) {...}

The raw type will also compile (with a warning):

  @Override
  Dog createFromList(List cells) {...}

Why when the return type is Dog the method with the raw type compiles (with a warning) and the method with List<Object> won't and in the same time it will compile if the return type is T?

answers.title: Add multiple choice to Dialog and make it functioning
answers.body:
This is a way to get what you want, you can take this idea and do something like this with a CardLayout and a JFrame. You're asking for JDialogs so I made an example with them:

You should also check Making a JOptionPane with 4 options, I also used a ternary operator and you should also read How to make Dialogs, so you can add more complex GUI into them, such as those buttons and a JTextField and images, etc., like: this one or this one or this one, just use Google or the search tool bar on the right top corner of this site.

import java.awt.*;
import javax.swing.*;
public class DialogExamples {
    String[] answers = new String[] {"A1", "A2", "A3", "A4"};
    String[] questions = new String[] {"Q1", "Q2", "Q3", "Your score: "};
    int response = -2; //-2 because I'm not sure what value does response has, -1 or 3 on the last option
    int i = 0;
    int score = 0;
    String message = "";
    public DialogExamples() {
        do {
            message = i < 3 ? questions[i] : questions[i] + score;
            while (response != 0) { //Correct answer is A1
                response = JOptionPane.showOptionDialog(null, message, "Title",
                    JOptionPane.DEFAULT_OPTION, JOptionPane.PLAIN_MESSAGE,
                    null, answers, answers[0]);
            }
            i++;
            score++; //Add your logic
            response = -2;
        } while (i < questions.length); //i = number of questions
    }

    public static void main (String args[]) {
        DialogExamples de = new DialogExamples();
    }
}

This will give you an output similar to these ones, and you might have to edit it to fit your code and remove an error on my code which adds answer buttons even on the last dialog (just add a validation, but I'm only giving you the idea, so it's up to you to do the rest).

The 1st and last dialogs

    import java.awt.*;

//Call main GUI

//Main Method

//Edit the mainGUI

        /*titleLbl = new JLabel("Vocab Helper", JLabel.CENTER);
        subtitle = new JLabel("Choose a category to continue", JLabel.CENTER);
        mainFrame.add(titleLbl);

//new class for multiple choice logic

    import java.util.ArrayList;

/**
   A question with multiple choices.
*/

    public class ChoiceQuestion {
    private ArrayList<String> choices;

   /**
      Constructs a choice question with no choices.
   */

    public ChoiceQuestion()
    {
       choices = new ArrayList<String>();
    }

   /**
      Adds an answer choice to this question.
      @param choice the choice to add
      @param correct true if this is the correct choice, false otherwise
   */

     public void addChoice(String choice, boolean correct)
     {
      choices.add(choice);
      if (correct) 
      {
         // Convert choices.size() to string
         String choiceString = "" + choices.size();
         setAnswer(choiceString);
      }
   }

    public void display()
    {
        // Display the question text
        super.display();
        // Display the answer choices
        for (int i = 0; i < choices.size(); i++)
        {
          int choiceNumber = i + 1;
          System.out.println(choiceNumber + ": " + choices.get(i));     
          }
        }
     }

//class for the quiz where the quiz is created.

      import java.util.ArrayList;
      import java.util.Scanner;

/**
   A quiz contains a list of questions.
*/

      public class Quiz
      {
      private ArrayList<Question> questions;

   /**
      Constructs a quiz with no questions.
   */

     public Quiz()
     {
       questions = new ArrayList<Question>();
     }

   /**
      Adds a question to this quiz.
      @param q the question
   */

     public void addQuestion(Question q)
     {
       questions.add(q);
     }

   /**
      Presents the questions to the user and checks the response.
   */

     public void presentQuestions()
     {
        Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);

        for (Question q : questions)
        {
           q.display();
           System.out.print("Your answer: ");
           String response = in.nextLine();
           System.out.println(q.checkAnswer(response));\
//over here display this question but in the dialog and with bubbles that they can click on.
       }
    }
 }

answers.title: option menu button is not showing when use theme of main activity NoActionBar
answers.body:
Because you're using NoActionBar theme, so there's no action bar in your activity. In order to show your menu in your activity, the best method is adding Toolbar as your actionbar as this Google Guide - Set up the app bar:

// add toolbar to your layout xml
<android.support.v7.widget.Toolbar
android:id="@+id/my_toolbar"
android:layout_width="match_parent"
android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize"
android:background="?attr/colorPrimary"
android:elevation="4dp"
android:theme="@style/ThemeOverlay.AppCompat.ActionBar"
app:popupTheme="@style/ThemeOverlay.AppCompat.Light"/>


// set toolbar as actionbar in your activity
Toolbar myToolbar = (Toolbar) findViewById(R.id.my_toolbar);
setSupportActionBar(myToolbar);

    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:background="#02443B"
    android:minHeight="?attr/actionBarSize"

    app:layout_constraintEnd_toEndOf="parent"

Then do this below your onCreate the option menu will appear

Toolbar myToolbar = (Toolbar) findViewById(R.id.toolbar4);
setSupportActionBar(myToolbar);

answers.body_markdown:
Read this Github issue -> https://github.com/mailgun/mailgun-php/issues/617

Unfortunately, **MailGun** supports email validation only on **US** Servers and not on **EU** servers.

-----
**Solution:** 

- Try to host the MailGun Server in the **US** region to make the **email validation** to work. 

- I see that Email Validation is only offered via **v4** APIs.

- I'm not sure but I guess **v4** features are not free to use and you will need to purchase a subscription to make the **v4** API to work.

- You will need to use only **private key** when it comes to **v4** APIs.

Screenshot from IntelliJ for MailGun Java SDK:

[![enter image description here][1]][1]


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/MdT6Y.png
answers.title: How to validate an email in Java code using Mailgun from a domain present in EU?
answers.body:
Read this Github issue -> https://github.com/mailgun/mailgun-php/issues/617

Unfortunately, MailGun supports email validation only on US Servers and not on EU servers.

Solution:

  • Try to host the MailGun Server in the US region to make the email validation to work.

  • I see that Email Validation is only offered via v4 APIs.

  • I'm not sure but I guess v4 features are not free to use and you will need to purchase a subscription to make the v4 API to work.

  • You will need to use only private key when it comes to v4 APIs.

Screenshot from IntelliJ for MailGun Java SDK:

When a method does not work as expected, it's a good idea to check the API. The [StringBuilder API](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/StringBuilder.html) has this note: *"API Note:
StringBuilder implements Comparable but does not override equals. Thus, the natural ordering of StringBuilder is inconsistent with equals. "* (in part).
comments.body: When a method does not work as expected, it's a good idea to check the API. The StringBuilder API has this note: "API Note: StringBuilder implements Comparable but does not override equals. Thus, the natural ordering of StringBuilder is inconsistent with equals. " (in part).

comments.body_markdown: look at this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18565701/stringbuilder-equals-java
comments.body: look at this: stackoverflow.com/questions/18565701/stringbuilder-equals-ja‌​va

answers.title: StringBuilder equals() method is not working as expected
answers.body:
This part of your code is the problem:

if(s2.equals(s1)) {
    return true;
}

What you are doing here is comparing two StringBuilder objects, and they are obviously always different. What you should to instead is to compare the Strings that are build using those builders. To get the string from the builder you need to use toString method. So, your code should look like that:

if(s2.toString().equals(s1.toString())) {
    return true;
}

I've tested your code with this change and it works correctly now. I hope it helps.

answers.title: StringBuilder equals() method is not working as expected
answers.body:
Change

if(s2.equals(s1)) {
      return true;
}

to

if (s2.compareTo(s1) == 0) {
      return true;
 }

answers.title: StringBuilder equals() method is not working as expected
answers.body:
You could simplify the whole process by using a Regular Expression passed to the String#replaceAll() method, for example:

class Solution {
    public boolean isPalindrome(String s) {
        String regEx = "\\p{Punct}|\\s+";
        return s.replaceAll(regEx, "").equalsIgnoreCase(
                new StringBuilder(s).reverse().toString().replaceAll(regEx, ""));
    }
}

What does the used Regular Expression mean?

  • \\p{Punct} All punctuation and special characters;
  • | OR;
  • \\s+ Any white-space character (equivalent to: \r (Carraige Return), \n (Newline or Linefeed), \t (Tab), \f (Formfeed), etc) one or unlimited times.

answers.title: StringBuilder equals() method is not working as expected
answers.body:
You can circumvent the problem of missing StringBuilder.equals by not using it. Instead, you can directly compare characters of the filtered string:

public static boolean isPalindrome(String s) {
    var filtered = s.codePoints()
            .filter(Character::isLetterOrDigit)
            .map(Character::toLowerCase)
            .collect(StringBuilder::new, StringBuilder::appendCodePoint, StringBuilder::append);
    var length = filtered.length();
    return IntStream.range(0, length / 2)
            .allMatch(i -> filtered.codePointAt(i) == filtered.codePointAt(length - 1 - i));
}

items.title: StringBuilder equals() method is not working as expected
items.body:
I am solving the 125. Valid Palindrome problem in leetcode. For testcase

A man, a plan, a canal: Panama

with below code, it is returning false:

class Solution {
    public boolean isPalindrome(String s) {
        StringBuilder s1 = new StringBuilder();
        StringBuilder s2 = new StringBuilder();
        for (int i = 0; i < s.length(); i++) {
            char curr = s.charAt(i);
            if ((curr <= 57 && curr >= 48) || (curr >= 97 && curr <= 122) || (curr <= 90 && curr >= 65)) {
                curr = Character.toLowerCase(curr);
                s1.append(curr);
            }
        }
        s2.append(s1);
        s2.reverse();
        if (s2.equals(s1)) {
            return true;
        }
        return false;
    }
}
